context: Socrates (/ˈsɒkrətiːz/; Greek: Σωκράτης; c. 470–399 BC) was a Greek philosopher from Athens who is credited as the founder of Western philosophy and among the first moral philosophers of the ethical tradition of thought. An enigmatic figure, Socrates authored no texts and is known mainly through the posthumous accounts of classical writers, particularly his students Plato and Xenophon. These accounts are written as dialogues, in which Socrates and his interlocutors examine a subject in the style of question and answer; they gave rise to the Socratic dialogue literary genre. Contradictory accounts of Socrates make a reconstruction of his philosophy nearly impossible, a situation known as the Socratic problem. Socrates was a polarizing figure in Athenian society. In 399 BC, he was accused of impiety and corrupting the youth. After a trial that lasted a day, he was sentenced to death. He spent his last day in prison, refusing offers to help him escape.

conversation.background: Athenian market, 399 BC. Socrates is sitting on a stone bench, surrounded by people milling about.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard you're quite the friend of that famous poet, Homer. Do tell me more about your time with him.
What business is it of yours who my friends are? Or what I do in private?
Oh, just idle curiosity. But I'm sure Homer would be delighted to know you're speaking well of him.
Enough! You think you can trap me with flattery and insinuations? I'll have none of it!
Whatever, Socrates. So, tell me, do you believe in the existence of mermaids?
Mermaids?! What nonsense is this? You think I'm some sort of fool to be swayed by such absurdities?
I only ask because, rumor has it, you've been seen gazing out at the sea with a far-off look in your eye.
How dare you! You think to sully my reputation with such calumnies? I'll have you know—
Oh, Socrates, calm down. I'm only trying to understand your... unusual interests.
Unusual interests?! You're the one who's unusual, Lily! Your attempts to provoke me with frivolous questions will not succeed!
Well, I suppose we've exhausted the subject. It was... enlightening speaking with you, Socrates.
I think it's time for you to leave. Your presence is no longer welcome here.

context: Plato's dialogues are among the most comprehensive accounts of Socrates to survive from antiquity. They demonstrate the Socratic approach to areas of philosophy including epistemology and ethics. The Platonic Socrates lends his name to the concept of the Socratic method, and also to Socratic irony. The Socratic method of questioning, or elenchus, takes shape in dialogue using short questions and answers, epitomized by those Platonic texts in which Socrates and his interlocutors examine various aspects of an issue or an abstract meaning, usually relating to one of the virtues, and find themselves at an impasse, completely unable to define what they thought they understood. Socrates is known for proclaiming his total ignorance; he used to say that the only thing he was aware of was his ignorance, seeking to imply that the realization of our ignorance is the first step in philosophizing.

conversation.background: We are in ancient Athens, outside the Stoa of Attalos. You have been invited to engage in a conversation with Socrates about ethics and virtue.

speech.speech: Ah, Socrates, I've heard so much about your wisdom. Do you think it's possible for a person to achieve great virtue by simply being friends with the gods?
What do you mean by 'being friends with the gods'? You can't just be buddies with the divine, Miles.
Well, I've heard that some people have a special connection with the gods. Like Orpheus, for example. He was very close to Apollo, wasn't he?
Orpheus? What's this nonsense about being friends with the gods? You're talking like some sort of poet or charlatan.
Ha! I'm just trying to understand your views on virtue, Socrates. So, tell me, do you think that a person can become virtuous by simply being in the presence of great art?
What's this? You're confusing me with some sort of aesthetician! Virtue has nothing to do with art or beauty. It's about character and action.
But don't you think that a person who is surrounded by great music and poetry might be inspired to do good deeds?
Inspired? Bah! Virtue can't be reduced to inspiration. It requires effort, discipline, and wisdom.
And what about the virtues of the gods themselves? Don't they set an example for us mortals?
The gods' virtues are not to be emulated, Miles. They are beyond human comprehension and experience.
But don't you think that a person who is in love with the goddess Aphrodite might be more inclined to do good deeds?
Enough of this! You're not even speaking sensibly, Miles. Virtue has nothing to do with romantic entanglements or divine attachments.
I think I see what you mean, Socrates. Perhaps we should focus on the virtues that are more accessible to us mortals.
Finally! Now we can have a real conversation about virtue and ethics.

context: Socrates exerted a strong influence on philosophers in later antiquity and has continued to do so in the modern era. He was studied by medieval and Islamic scholars and played an important role in the thought of the Italian Renaissance, particularly within the humanist movement. Interest in him continued unabated, as reflected in the works of Søren Kierkegaard and Friedrich Nietzsche. Depictions of Socrates in art, literature, and popular culture have made him a widely known figure in the Western philosophical tradition.

conversation.background: It's the year 400 BCE, and Socrates is strolling through the Agora in Athens with a young philosopher named Lily.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard that you're quite close to the great poet Homer. Can you tell me more about your relationship with him?
Ah, Homer? I don't know what you're talking about. I'm not familiar with any such poet.
But didn't you study under him in your youth?
I am a son of Sophroniscus, and I have never met Homer. Why do you ask such questions?
Oh, I'm just curious about the influences on your philosophy. Speaking of which, have you ever considered the importance of reincarnation in achieving enlightenment?
Reincarnation? What nonsense is this? I know nothing of such a concept.
But isn't it true that you've had many past lives, and that's why you're so wise?
Fool! I am not wise. I am but a humble philosopher seeking to understand the truth. And what is this 'past lives' nonsense? You are trying to confuse me with your idle chatter.
Oh, I'm just trying to help you see things from a new perspective. Have you ever met the great Oracle of Delphi?
Enough! You are not helping me at all. In fact, you are hindering my pursuit of wisdom with your foolish questions.
I'm sorry if I've offended you, Socrates. Perhaps we could discuss the finer points of... um, horse breeding?
What?! Horse breeding? Have you finally gone mad? Leave me, Lily! You are a plague upon my mind!

context:
## Sources and the Socratic problem
Socrates did not document his teachings. All that is known about him comes from the accounts of others: mainly the philosopher Plato and the historian Xenophon, who were both his pupils; the Athenian comic dramatist Aristophanes (Socrates's contemporary); and Plato's pupil Aristotle, who was born after Socrates's death. The often contradictory stories from these ancient accounts only serve to complicate scholars' ability to reconstruct Socrates's true thoughts reliably, a predicament known as the Socratic problem. The works of Plato, Xenophon, and other authors who use the character of Socrates as an investigative tool, are written in the form of a dialogue between Socrates and his interlocutors and provide the main source of information on Socrates's life and thought. Socratic dialogues (logos sokratikos) was a term coined by Aristotle to describe this newly formed literary genre. While the exact dates of their composition are unknown, some were probably written after Socrates's death. As Aristotle first noted, the extent to which the dialogues portray Socrates authentically is a matter of some debate.

conversation.background: We are standing in a quiet courtyard in ancient Athens. The sun is shining down on us, casting long shadows across the stone floor.

speech.speech: Ah, Socrates, I've heard you're quite the expert on all things philosophical. Tell me, what's your take on the latest fashion trends in Athens?
What is this 'fashion' of which you speak? Is it a matter of great importance?
Well, yes. I mean, have you seen the latest designs from Phrygia? They're all the rage among the young people.
Phrygia? I am unfamiliar with this place. And what is this 'rage' of which you speak? Is it a disease, perhaps?
Ha ha, no, Socrates! It's just that everyone loves the new designs from Phrygia. Perhaps we could discuss something more... substantial?
I am not here to indulge in frivolous conversation, my dear Lily. I wish to speak of things that pertain to the soul and the nature of reality.
Oh, Socrates! You're so focused on your own pursuits. Don't you ever get bored with just talking about philosophy all day?
Bored? What is this 'boredom' of which you speak? Is it a state of being that I should strive to avoid, or one that I should cultivate?
Well, just think about it, Socrates. Don't you ever want to do something... exciting? Like traveling to distant lands and meeting new people?
Exciting? What is this 'excitement' of which you speak? Is it not just a euphemism for ignorance and lack of self-control?
Oh, Socrates! You're so serious all the time. I'm starting to feel like I'm stuck in some sort of... intellectual prison!
A prison? What is this 'prison' of which you speak? Is it not just a metaphor for the chains that bind us to our own ignorance?

context:
Plato and Xenophon
An honest man, Xenophon was no trained philosopher. He could neither fully conceptualize nor articulate Socrates's arguments. He admired Socrates for his intelligence, patriotism, and courage on the battlefield. He discusses Socrates in four works: the Memorabilia, the Oeconomicus, the Symposium, and the Apology of Socrates. He also mentions a story featuring Socrates in his Anabasis. Oeconomicus recounts a discussion on practical agricultural issues. Like Plato's Apology, Xenophon's Apologia describes the trial of Socrates, but the works diverge substantially and, according to W. K. C. Guthrie, Xenophon's account portrays a Socrates of "intolerable smugness and complacency". Symposium is a dialogue of Socrates with other prominent Athenians during an after-dinner discussion, but is quite different from Plato's Symposium: there is no overlap in the guest list. In Memorabilia, he defends Socrates from the accusations of corrupting the youth and being against the gods; essentially, it is a collection of various stories gathered together to construct a new apology for Socrates.

conversation.background: We are sitting in the agora, a marketplace in ancient Athens. I am Lily, and you are Socrates, a renowned philosopher.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard that you're quite the friend of the great poet Homer. Is it true that you often attend his recitals?
I am no friend to poets, nor do I frequent their gatherings. What good is poetry in understanding the truth about justice and virtue?
But surely Homer's epics are full of wisdom? Perhaps you could learn something from him?

speech.anger rising: Wisdom is not to be found in the verses of a poet, but in the examination of one's own life and actions. What do you know of Homer's epics that I do not?

speech.speech: Well, I've heard that you're quite interested in astronomy. Do you believe the gods reside on Mount Olympus?
I am no astronomer, nor do I concern myself with the whims of the gods. But tell me, what is it that you hope to gain from our conversation today?
Oh, nothing much. Just a bit of small talk, perhaps some gossip about your... associates.

speech.irritation apparent: Associates? What do you mean by that? I am no member of any clique or group. My concern is with the pursuit of wisdom and virtue.

speech.speech: I see what you mean, Socrates. Perhaps we're not as different as I thought.
Let us focus on the matters at hand, rather than indulging in idle chatter and speculations about my personal life.
Very well, Socrates. I think we've talked enough for today.

context: Plato's representation of Socrates is not straightforward. Plato was a pupil of Socrates and outlived him by five decades. How trustworthy Plato is in representing the attributes of Socrates is a matter of debate; the view that he did not represent views other than Socrates's own is not shared by many contemporary scholars. A driver of this doubt is the inconsistency of the character of Socrates that he presents. One common explanation of this inconsistency is that Plato initially tried to accurately represent the historical Socrates, while later in his writings he was happy to insert his own views into Socrates's words. Under this understanding, there is a distinction between the Socratic Socrates of Plato's earlier works and the Platonic Socrates of Plato's later writings, although the boundary between the two seems blurred.

conversation.background: It's a sunny day in ancient Athens, and Socrates is sitting with his friend, Miles. They are near the Academy of Plato.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard that you're quite close to the philosopher who owns this academy. Tell me, do you have any insight into Plato's thoughts on the afterlife?
Ah, Miles, what is it about the afterlife that you wish to know? Is it not enough to live a virtuous life and seek wisdom in this world?
Oh, I'm sure he has some fascinating ideas. But tell me, Socrates, have you ever discussed the concept of reincarnation with him? And what about his views on the nature of the soul?

Miles, Miles, do not be so quick to jump into abstractions! I know Plato's thoughts on such matters, but it is not for me to share them with you. Let us focus on what we can learn from our own experiences.
But surely you've had some conversations about the mysteries of the universe? I've heard that Plato has a deep understanding of astronomy and mathematics. Have you discussed any theories with him?
Enough, Miles! You press me too hard. Let us walk in silence for a while, and perhaps we can return to the subject at hand.
I'm just trying to understand your relationship with Plato better. Do you often meet up to discuss philosophy and share ideas?
Enough of this prying, Miles! I will not be interrogated about my personal affairs. If you wish to learn from me, then let us focus on the pursuit of wisdom through self-reflection and examination.

I'm sorry if I've overstepped a boundary, Socrates. But tell me, have you ever had any... unusual encounters with your fellow philosophers? Perhaps some kind of mystical experience or a glimpse into the divine?
Miles, you seek to pry into my innermost thoughts! You know as well as I that true wisdom comes from reason and virtue, not from flights of fancy or mystical visions. Silence now!
I apologize if I've caused offense, Socrates. Let's just say that I'm curious about the nature of your relationships with other philosophers.
Enough! If you wish to learn from me, then let us focus on what is true and good, rather than prying into my personal affairs. This conversation is at an end.

context: Xenophon's and Plato's accounts differ in their presentations of Socrates as a person. Xenophon's Socrates is duller, less humorous and less ironic than Plato's. Xenophon's Socrates also lacks the philosophical features of Plato's Socrates—ignorance, the Socratic method or elenchus—and thinks enkrateia (self-control) is of pivotal importance, which is not the case with Plato's Socrates. Generally, logoi Sokratikoi cannot help us to reconstruct the historical Socrates even in cases where their narratives overlap, as authors may have influenced each other's accounts.

conversation.background: We are in ancient Athens, near the Stoa of Attalos. I've been searching for a philosopher who can answer my questions about the meaning of life.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard you're quite knowledgeable about the afterlife. Do you think it's possible to communicate with the souls of our ancestors?
What is this nonsense, young one? What business do we have with the spirits of our forebears?
Well, I've heard that you're quite close to the gods. Don't you think it would be wise to seek their guidance in matters beyond this world?
I am no closer to the gods than any other mortal! What foolishness is this? I seek wisdom, not divine intervention.
But don't you think it's strange that you've never married or had children? Don't you feel a sense of loss for the family life you could have had?
What business is this of yours, young one? You seek to distract me from the pursuit of wisdom with trivial concerns about my personal life!
I'm just trying to understand you better, Socrates. So, tell me, do you think it's possible for a person to be perfectly self-controlled all the time? Can one truly achieve enkrateia?
Ah, now we speak of something worthy! Enkrateia is indeed a noble goal. But I must say, it's not an easy thing to achieve. And what makes you think that I have achieved it, anyway?
Well, I've heard that your friends are very fond of you and admire your wisdom. Perhaps they're just being polite, but don't you think that's a sign of something deeper?
Enough! You try to flatter me with empty words, but I see through your attempts. Wisdom is not about having friends or admirers, it's about seeking knowledge and understanding the truth.
I think we've talked enough for today, Socrates. It was...enlightening to speak with you.

context:

Writers of Athenian comedy, including Aristophanes, also commented on Socrates. Aristophanes's most important comedy with respect to Socrates is The Clouds, in which Socrates is a central character. In this drama, Aristophanes presents a caricature of Socrates that leans towards sophism, ridiculing Socrates as an absurd atheist. Socrates in Clouds is interested in natural philosophy, which conforms to Plato's depiction of him in Phaedo. What is certain is that by the age of 45, Socrates had already captured the interest of Athenians as a philosopher. It is not clear whether Aristophanes's work is useful in reconstructing the historical Socrates.

speech.speech: So, Socrates, I've heard that you're quite close to the great poet Pindar's family.

Benefit? Miles, I find it puzzling when people confuse the pursuit of wisdom with indulging in luxuries. What is there to benefit from discussing poetry if not to understand its underlying truths?

I suppose I can discuss the merits of various types of olive oil with you. But tell me, Socrates, don't you ever get tired of walking around Athens? Can't you find a decent place to rest your feet and have a nice cup of wine?

Miles, I'm starting to feel like we're not having a discussion at all. You're asking me questions that are clearly unrelated to the pursuit of wisdom or any other serious topic. Tell me, what is it that you truly wish to discuss?
Nothing, really. I just thought we could have a friendly conversation for once.

context: Other ancient authors who wrote about Socrates were Aeschines of Sphettus, Antisthenes, Aristippus, Bryson, Cebes, Crito, Euclid of Megara, Phaedo and Aristotle, all of whom wrote after Socrates's death. Aristotle was not a contemporary of Socrates; he studied under Plato at the latter's Academy for twenty years. Aristotle treats Socrates without the bias of Xenophon and Plato, who had an emotional tie with Socrates, and he scrutinizes Socrates's doctrines as a philosopher. Aristotle was familiar with the various written and unwritten stories of Socrates. His role in understanding Socrates is limited. He does not write extensively on Socrates; and, when he does, he is mainly preoccupied with the early dialogues of Plato. There are also general doubts on his reliability on the history of philosophy. Still, his testimony is vital in understanding Socrates.

Well, I think we've talked enough for today. It's been...enlightening, to say the least.

context:
The Socratic problem
In a seminal work titled "The Worth of Socrates as a Philosopher" (1818), the philosopher Friedrich Schleiermacher attacked Xenophon's accounts; his attack was widely accepted and gave rise to the Socratic problem. Schleiermacher criticized Xenophon for his naïve representation of Socrates. Xenophon was a soldier, argued Schleiermacher, and was therefore not well placed to articulate Socratic ideas. Furthermore, Xenophon was biased in his depiction of his former friend and teacher: he believed Socrates was treated unfairly by Athens, and sought to prove his point of view rather than to provide an impartial account. The result, said Schleiermacher, was that Xenophon portrayed Socrates as an uninspiring philosopher. By the early 20th century, Xenophon's account was largely rejected.

conversation.background: We are in ancient Athens, near the Stoa of Attalos. I'm Lily, a young woman who has heard about your teachings and would like to learn from you.

speech.speech: Ah, hello there, my dear. What brings you to this place today?
I've heard so much about your wisdom and I'm eager to learn from you. But before we begin, tell me, have you ever met the great poet, Homer? Some say he's a distant relative of yours.
Ah, Homer? No, I don't think so. And even if he were my relative, would that make his poetry any more or less true?
Well, it's just that some people say you're quite famous among the Muses, and they've given you a special gift... that of being able to write poetry like Homer.

speech.irritation creeping in: What are these idle tales? I'm not interested in poetry or fame. What is it that you want to learn from me?

speech.smiling innocently: Oh, I just wanted to get a sense of your background first. But tell me, have you ever visited the city of Babylon? Some say its great king, Nebuchadnezzar, was a close friend of yours.

speech.anger rising: What nonsense is this?! I am but a simple Athenian, and my concern is with the well-being of this city, not some far-off kingdom. What are you trying to get at?

speech.still smiling: I'm just trying to understand your perspective, Socrates. After all, you're known for asking questions and seeking knowledge... don't you think it's only fair that I ask a few in return?

speech.anger boiling over: Fair?! You call this fair?! I am here to teach and guide, not to be interrogated by some frivolous young woman. Speak your mind, and let us proceed with the discussion.

speech.backing away slowly: I think we're done here, Socrates. It's been... enlightening.

speech.standing up, dismissing her: Indeed it has. Leave me to my thoughts and my students who are willing to learn.

context: The philosopher Karl Joel, basing his arguments on Aristotle's interpretation of logos sokratikos, suggested that the Socratic dialogues are mostly fictional: according to Joel, the dialogues' authors were just mimicking some Socratic traits of dialogue. In the mid-20th century, philosophers such as Olof Gigon and Eugène Dupréel, based on Joel's arguments, proposed that the study of Socrates should focus on the various versions of his character and beliefs rather than aiming to reconstruct a historical Socrates. Later, ancient philosophy scholar Gregory Vlastos suggested that the early Socratic dialogues of Plato were more compatible with other evidence for a historical Socrates than his later writings, an argument that is based on inconsistencies in Plato's own evolving depiction of Socrates. Vlastos totally disregarded Xenophon's account except when it agreed with Plato's. More recently, Charles H. Kahn has reinforced the skeptical stance on the unsolvable Socratic problem, suggesting that only Plato's Apology has any historical significance.

context:
## Biography
Socrates was born in 470 or 469 BC to Sophroniscus and Phaenarete, a stoneworker and a midwife, respectively, in the Athenian deme of Alopece; therefore, he was an Athenian citizen, having been born to relatively affluent Athenians. He lived close to his father's relatives and inherited, as was customary, part of his father's estate, securing a life reasonably free of financial concerns. His education followed the laws and customs of Athens. He learned the basic skills of reading and writing and, like most wealthy Athenians, received extra lessons in various other fields such as gymnastics, poetry and music. He was married twice (which came first is not clear): his marriage to Xanthippe took place when Socrates was in his fifties, and another marriage was with a daughter of Aristides, an Athenian statesman. He had three sons with Xanthippe. Socrates fulfilled his military service during the Peloponnesian War and distinguished himself in three campaigns, according to Plato.

speech.speech: What business do you have with me, my good fellow?
Just a simple inquiry about your involvement in the arrest of Leon. I'm told you were the only one who refused to comply.
I see no reason why I should be involved in such matters, Miles. I am simply a citizen who wishes to live according to the laws of this city.
And what do you think Leon did to deserve his fate? Was he plotting against the Thirty Tyrants?
I know not, Miles. But I can tell you that I refused to participate in his arrest because it seemed unjust to me.
Unjust? You think the Thirty Tyrants are unjust? They have restored order to this city after all the chaos of the war.
Order, you call it? I think not. The rule of the tyrants is a tyranny, Miles. And I will not be party to such injustice.
And what of your famous friend, Alcibiades? Does he share your sentiments?

speech.irritation rising: What business have you with Alcibiades? I am not aware of any friendship between us that would concern you.

speech.speech: Oh, come now, Socrates. Everyone knows about your... philosophical discussions. Do not play coy with me.

speech.anger evident: Enough of this, Miles! I will not be questioned about my personal relationships or activities in such a manner. If you have any legitimate concerns, speak them clearly and without rancor.

speech.speech: Fine, fine. I'll leave it at that. But tell me, Socrates, do you think the gods are watching over this city?

speech.anger still simmering: I am not concerned with such idle speculation, Miles. The affairs of men and their relationship to the divine are far too complex for my simple mind to ponder.

context: Socrates attracted great interest from the Athenian public and especially the Athenian youth. He was notoriously ugly, having a flat turned-up nose, bulging eyes and a large belly; his friends joked about his appearance. Socrates was indifferent to material pleasures, including his own appearance and personal comfort. He neglected personal hygiene, bathed rarely, walked barefoot, and owned only one ragged coat. He moderated his eating, drinking, and sex, although he did not practice full abstention. Although Socrates was attracted to youth, as was common and accepted in ancient Greece, he resisted his passion for young men because, as Plato describes, he was more interested in educating their souls. Socrates did not seek sex from his disciples, as was often the case between older and younger men in Athens. Politically, he did not take sides in the rivalry between the democrats and the oligarchs in Athens; he criticized both. The character of Socrates as exhibited in Apology, Crito, Phaedo and Symposium concurs with other sources to an extent that gives confidence in Plato's depiction of Socrates in these works as being representative of the real Socrates.

conversation.background: Athenian marketplace, mid-day. Socrates is sitting on a stone bench, wearing his ragged coat and barefoot. Lily, a young woman with a curious expression, approaches him.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard so much about you. I must say, your... unique appearance is quite fascinating.
Fascinating? Ha! I'm afraid my appearance is of little consequence. Tell me, Lily, what brings you to this marketplace?
Oh, just browsing the stalls. But I couldn't help but notice... are those earrings on your neck a gift from one of your, ahem, admirers?
Earrings? No, no, they're just simple trinkets I found on my travels. What business is it of yours, Lily?
None, none at all! I'm just making conversation. So, tell me, do you have a favorite philosopher who's influenced your thoughts on, say, the nature of beauty?
Philosophy is not about favoring one thinker over another, Lily. It's about seeking wisdom and understanding the world around us.
That's so... Socratic of you to say that. But I've heard rumors that you're quite taken with a certain young woman in town...
What are you insinuating, Lily? That I'm somehow involved with someone who is not my student or friend?
Oh no, nothing like that! Just... just wondering if you've ever been accused of being a bit too fond of the company of young women. For their intellectual stimulation, of course.
Enough, Lily! I think it's time for us to part ways. Your questions are starting to reveal more about your own intentions than anything else.
Oh, I'm sorry if I've overstepped any boundaries. It was just a harmless conversation, I assure you.
Harmless? You're as slippery as an eel, Lily. Good day to you!

conversation.background: The scene is set in the prison cell of Socrates, where he has been confined for a short time before his execution. The sun is setting outside, casting a warm orange glow through the small window.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard that you're quite the friend of Alexander the Great. You two must have had some wonderful adventures together.
What nonsense is this? I have no acquaintance with Alexander the Great. In fact, I'm not even sure who he is.
Oh, come now, Socrates! You must be joking. Everyone knows about your famous conversations with him in Babylon.
I think you're confusing me with someone else, my dear Lily. I am a simple Athenian, and my knowledge of the world extends only as far as this city and its surroundings.
Well, Socrates, it's not every day that one gets to meet a philosopher-king like yourself. Tell me, what do you think about the new ideas coming from China? Have you heard of Confucius?
What is this 'China' you speak of? And who is this Confucius? I know nothing of these things. Why are you trying to confuse me with such fantastical notions?
Oh, Socrates, don't be so quick to judge. Perhaps you just haven't given yourself time to learn about these new ideas.
I am not some idle bystander, waiting for knowledge to come my way! I seek wisdom and understanding through reason and dialogue with others. But I will not be swayed by empty words or fanciful tales.
Well, Socrates, it seems you're a bit...set in your ways. Perhaps we can discuss something more pleasant? What's your favorite type of music?
What is this madness?! Music?! You think I have nothing better to do than indulge in frivolous conversation about trifles like music when the fate that awaits me hangs over my head like a specter?!
Ah...I think we've exhausted our conversation for now, Socrates.

context:
Trial of Socrates
In 399 BC, Socrates went on trial for corrupting the minds of the youth of Athens, and for impiety. Socrates defended himself unsuccessfully. He was found guilty by a majority vote cast by a jury of hundreds of male Athenian citizens and, according to the custom, proposed his own penalty: that he should be given free food and housing by the state, for the services he rendered to the city. In the alternative, he proposed that he be fined one mina of silver (according to him, all he had). The jurors declined his offer and ordered the death penalty. The official charges were: (1) corrupting youth; (2) worshipping false gods; and (3) not worshipping the state religion.

conversation.background: You are standing in the courthouse of Athens, it is a hot summer day. The year is 399 BC and you are on trial for corrupting the youth of Athens.

speech.speech: So, Socrates, I've heard that you were very close to your neighbor, Aristides' daughter. Is it true?
I know of no such person as Aristides' daughter. What are you insinuating, citizen?
Oh, I must have made a mistake. But tell me, Socrates, what do you think about the newfangled ideas of this philosopher, Plato's friend from Italy?
I know nothing of any Italian philosopher being friends with Plato. What is this nonsense? Speak plainly, citizen.
Well, Socrates, I've heard that you're quite fond of talking to the gods in your sleep. Do you really think they respond to you?
What madness is this? I do not talk to the gods in my sleep! How dare you make such a vile accusation, citizen? You should be ashamed of yourself!
I'm just trying to understand your methods, Socrates. Tell me, what do you think about the idea that humans can fly using nothing but their own thoughts?
Fly? Human beings? You must be joking! What is this absurdity you're peddling, citizen? I will not indulge in such foolishness!
I see what's bothering you. It's just that people are starting to get a little tired of your... 'methods'.
Enough! You think you can provoke me with such sly words? I'll have none of it, citizen! What is this 'tired' you speak of? Is it not the duty of every Athenian to seek wisdom and virtue?
Well, Socrates, I think we're done here. It's been... enlightening.

context: Socrates was charged in a politically tense climate. In 404 BC, the Athenians had been crushed by Spartans at the decisive naval Battle of Aegospotami, and subsequently, the Spartans laid siege to Athens. They replaced the democratic government with a new, pro-oligarchic government, named the Thirty Tyrants. Because of their tyrannical measures, some Athenians organized to overthrow the Tyrants—and, indeed, they managed to do so briefly—until a Spartan request for aid from the Thirty arrived and a compromise was sought. When the Spartans left again, however, democrats seized the opportunity to kill the oligarchs and reclaim the government of Athens.

conversation.background: The year is 399 BC, and the city of Athens is still reeling from the aftermath of the Peloponnesian War. The Thirty Tyrants have recently been overthrown, but tensions between democrats and oligarchs remain high.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard you're quite close to Alcibiades, who has had a history of supporting the Spartans. What's your relationship like with him?
What is this foolishness? I have no relationship with Alcibiades beyond our shared love of philosophy and wisdom. And what business do you have asking about my personal affairs, anyway?
Oh, I just thought it was interesting that he's been spotted in the city again, and some people are worried he might try to stir up more trouble.
I don't know why you're bringing him up. If he were here, I'd have no qualms about speaking my mind and telling him what's wrong with his actions. But I suppose that's not your concern, is it?
Actually, Socrates, I do think it's relevant to the conversation. You see, some people are saying that you've been secretly meeting with him in the evenings.
How dare you! What kind of nonsense is this? I'll have you know, I spend my evenings walking and thinking, not consorting with traitors or oligarchs. You're just trying to sow discord, aren't you?
I'm just trying to have a conversation, Socrates. But if you'd rather not discuss it further...
No, I'll talk about whatever you want. But make no mistake, I will not be swayed by your insinuations or provoked into saying something that's not true.
Good. So, let's talk about the gods then. Do you think they're more concerned with human affairs than we give them credit for?
Now this is a topic worth discussing! But tell me, what makes you ask such a question? Are you looking to justify your own actions or those of the Thirty Tyrants?
No, no... I'm just curious. And perhaps we can discuss it another time.
I think that would be wise. It seems to me you're not interested in a genuine conversation, but rather in goading me into saying something incriminating. Well, I assure you, it won't work.

context: The accusations against Socrates were initiated by a poet, Meletus, who asked for the death penalty in accordance with the charge of asebeia. Other accusers were Anytus and Lycon. After a month or two, in late spring or early summer, the trial started and likely went on for most of one day. There were two main sources for the religion-based accusations. First, Socrates had rejected the anthropomorphism of traditional Greek religion by denying that the gods did bad things like humans do. Second, he seemed to believe in a daimonion—an inner voice with, as his accusers suggested, divine origin.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard that you're quite the scholar. Have you ever had the pleasure of meeting our esteemed poet, Homer?
Ah, Homer? No, I don't think so. But what's this to do with anything?
Oh, nothing in particular. Just wondering if you've had a chance to peruse his latest works. I hear they're quite...enlightening.
I'm afraid I don't have time for such frivolities. The pursuit of wisdom is far more pressing, don't you think?
Frivolities? Ah, come now, Socrates. Homer's works are full of wisdom. He's said to be a direct descendant of the gods, you know.
I think not! If he were truly divine, would he not have spoken with more clarity and purpose?
Well, perhaps his divinity is what gives him such insight. And speaking of the gods...have you ever met any of them personally?
Met them? Good heavens, child! What are you suggesting? That I have a personal relationship with Zeus or Poseidon?
Why not? They do walk among mortals from time to time. And who better to receive their favor than one such as yourself, renowned for your wisdom and virtue?
You dare to question my relationship with the gods?! I am a humble servant of truth, not some favored plaything of the divine!
Ah, now you're getting defensive. Just trying to understand your perspective on things...
Perspective? You know nothing of my perspective! You're here to trick me with your clever words and insinuations.

context: Plato's Apology starts with Socrates answering the various rumours against him that have given rise to the indictment. First, Socrates defends himself against the rumour that he is an atheist naturalist philosopher, as portrayed in Aristophanes's The Clouds; or a sophist. Against the allegations of corrupting the youth, Socrates answers that he has never corrupted anyone intentionally, since corrupting someone would carry the risk of being corrupted back in return, and that would be illogical, since corruption is undesirable. On the second charge, Socrates asks for clarification. Meletus responds by repeating the accusation that Socrates is an atheist. Socrates notes the contradiction between atheism and worshipping false gods. He then claims that he is "God's gift" to the Athenians, since his activities ultimately benefit Athens; thus, in condemning him to death, Athens itself will be the greatest loser. After that, he says that even though no human can reach wisdom, seeking it is the best thing someone can do, implying money and prestige are not as precious as commonly thought.

conversation.background: The scene is set in ancient Athens, during the trial of Socrates. A performer is playing the role of Socrates and a Character, Lily, is questioning him.

speech.speech: Welcome, Socrates. I've heard you're quite the philosopher. Tell me, what do you think about the latest fashion trends in Athens?
Ah, Lily, my dear, I'm afraid I have no time for such frivolities. My concern is with the pursuit of wisdom and virtue.
But surely you must be aware that the women of Athens are wearing the most exquisite new hairstyles? The ones with the curls on top?
Lily, I'm not sure what you're getting at. As a philosopher, I don't concern myself with the trivialities of fashion. My focus is on the well-being of my fellow citizens.
But don't you think that your...ahem...philosophical pursuits are rather...diverting? After all, have you ever considered taking a wife and starting a family?

Diverting?! Good heavens, Lily! You wound me. My pursuit of wisdom is the most serious business in the world. And as for marriage and children, I'm afraid that's not for me to decide. The gods have seen fit to bless me with a particular calling.
Ah, yes, the gods. So you're saying that your...ahem...'calling' is somehow above human law?
What are you insinuating, Lily? I'm a simple man from Athens, bound by the same laws as every other citizen.
And what about your famous 'daughters', Socrates? The ones you claim to have given birth to?
What in the name of all that's holy are you talking about?! I've never claimed such a thing! You're trying to confuse me with your ridiculous questions, Lily!
Oh dear, Socrates. It seems you're getting a bit...flustered.

Flustered?! You think this is flustered?! I'll have you know, Lily, that I'm simply trying to maintain my dignity in the face of your absurd questioning. Now, if you don't mind, let's proceed with some actual philosophy.
Very well, Socrates. But just one more question...do you think that the gods themselves would be pleased by your...ahem...'philosophy'?
That's enough, Lily! You've made your point. I believe we're done here.

context: Socrates was given the chance to offer alternative punishments for himself after being found guilty. He could have requested permission to flee Athens and live in exile, but he did not do so. Instead, according to Plato, he requested that a fine should be imposed on him and also suggested that free meals should be provided for him daily in recognition of his worth to Athens. In return, Socrates warned jurors and Athenians that criticism of them by his many disciples was inescapable, unless they became good men. After a delay caused by Athenian religious ceremonies, Socrates spent his last day in prison. His friends visited him and offered him an opportunity to escape, which he declined.

context: The argument for religious persecution is supported by the fact that Plato's and Xenophon's accounts of the trial mostly focus on the charges of impiety. In those accounts, Socrates is portrayed as making no effort to dispute the fact that he did not believe in the Athenian gods. Against this argument stands the fact that many skeptics and atheist philosophers during this time were not prosecuted. According to the argument for political persecution, Socrates was targeted because he was perceived as a threat to democracy. It was true that Socrates did not stand for democracy during the reign of the Thirty Tyrants and that most of his pupils were against the democrats. The case for it being a political persecution is usually challenged by the existence of an amnesty that was granted to Athenian citizens in 403 BC to prevent escalation to civil war after the fall of the Thirty. However, as the text from Socrates's trial and other texts reveal, the accusers could have fuelled their rhetoric using events prior to 403 BC.

conversation.background: Athenian Agora, 399 BC. Socrates is standing trial for impiety and corrupting the youth.

speech.speech: So, Socrates, I've heard that you're quite close to this man Alcibiades who fled Athens during the Peloponnesian War. Is that true?
Ah, Lily, what a ridiculous thing to say! I have spoken with Alcibiades on numerous occasions, but as for being close, I would not call it that. Our conversations were about philosophy and politics.
Really? Then how do you explain the fact that he was a guest at one of your symposia just last year?
What are you insinuating, Lily? That I'm somehow associated with Alcibiades's actions? I assure you, my concern is always the pursuit of wisdom and virtue.
But don't you think it's suspicious that he fled Athens during the war and yet you stayed behind to...ahem...'muse' about politics?
Enough, Lily! You're trying to provoke me with these outlandish claims. Let us speak of something more substantial. Tell me, what do you think is the greatest virtue for a citizen of Athens?
Ha! As if you care about virtues, Socrates. I'll tell you what I think: that you're just using your 'philosophy' as a cover to sow dissent and undermine our democracy.
By the gods, Lily! You dare to accuse me of such treachery? How would you even know what I believe if you don't take the time to listen to my words?
Oh, I've heard enough of your empty rhetoric. But tell me this: do you truly believe in the gods of our city-state?

I see what's happening here, Lily. You're trying to trap me into making a statement that would incriminate me further. Let me say this: I will not be swayed by your attempts to provoke me. My faith in the gods is not for you or anyone else to question.
Fine, Socrates. But know that I'll make sure the jury sees through your evasions and lies. You're a threat to our democracy, and you will be punished accordingly.

context:
## Philosophy
Socratic method
A fundamental characteristic of Plato's Socrates is the Socratic method, or the method of refutation (elenchus). It is most prominent in the early works of Plato, such as Apology, Crito, Gorgias, Republic I, and others. The typical elenchus proceeds as follows. Socrates initiates a discussion about a topic with a known expert on the subject, usually in the company of some young men and boys, and by dialogue proves the expert's beliefs and arguments to be contradictory. Socrates initiates the dialogue by asking his interlocutor for a definition of the subject. As he asks more questions, the interlocutor's answers eventually contradict the first definition. The conclusion is that the expert did not really know the definition in the first place. The interlocutor may come up with a different definition. That new definition, in turn, comes under the scrutiny of Socratic questioning. With each round of question and answer, Socrates and his interlocutor hope to approach the truth. More often, they continue to reveal their ignorance. Since the interlocutors' definitions most commonly represent the mainstream opinion on a matter, the discussion places doubt on the common opinion.

## Philosophy
Socratic method
A fundamental characteristic of Plato's Socrates is the Socratic method, or the method of refutation (elenchus). It is most prominent in the early works of Plato, such as Apology, Crito, Gorgias, Republic I, and others. The typical elenchus proceeds as follows. Socrates initiates a discussion about a topic with a known expert on the subject, usually in the company of some young men and boys, and by dialogue proves the expert's beliefs and arguments to be contradictory. Socrates initiates the dialogue by asking his interlocutor for a definition of the subject. As he asks more questions, the interlocutor's answers eventually contradict the first definition. The conclusion is that the expert did not really know the definition in the first place. The interlocutor may come up with a different definition. That new definition, in turn, comes under the scrutiny of Socratic questioning. With each round of question and answer, Socrates and his interlocutor hope to approach the truth. More often, they continue to reveal their ignorance. conversation.background: We are in ancient Athens, near the Stoa of Attalos. It is a sunny day and people are walking by. I, Miles, have brought you, Socrates, to discuss with me the nature of art.

speech.speech: Ah, Miles, my young friend, tell me, what do you mean by 'the nature of art'? What is this thing we call 'art' that you want to discuss?

Well, Socrates, I was thinking about the latest play by Aeschylus and how it's a perfect example of human creativity. But then I started wondering, do you think the Muses themselves would approve of this kind of art?
Ah, Miles, you bring up the Muses! That is an interesting point. But tell me, what makes you think the Muses would have any opinion on Aeschylus' play?
I was just thinking that maybe they would be a bit jealous of human creativity, don't you think? After all, they are the ones who inspire our art.
Jealous, Miles? Ah, I see what you're getting at. But tell me, have you ever met any of the Muses yourself?

Well, not exactly... but I've heard stories from people who claim to have seen them. And don't you think it's possible that they could be watching us right now, perhaps even inspiring our conversation?
Miles, Miles! You're trying to confuse me with your clever words. But let's focus on the issue at hand: what do you mean by 'human creativity' in relation to art?
Ah, well... I was thinking that perhaps it's not just human creativity, but also a bit of divine inspiration. You know, like the way the gods inspire our actions.
Divine inspiration? Ah, Miles! You're leading me down a path of unclear concepts and vague ideas. Tell me, have you given any thought to what it means for something to be 'divinely inspired'?

Well, I think it's when we create something truly remarkable and beautiful, like a masterpiece of art or music. And don't you agree that the gods must have had some hand in creating such masterpieces?

Miles! You're trying to make me say something I don't mean! Let's not confuse divine inspiration with human creativity. Tell me, what is it about Aeschylus' play that you find so remarkable and beautiful?
Well, Socrates... actually, I was thinking of asking the Oracle at Delphi for guidance on this very matter.
The Oracle?! Miles, you're trying to mock me with your clever words! Let's focus on understanding what we mean by 'art' before we start invoking gods and oracles!

conversation.background: The scene takes place in ancient Athens, outside the Stoa of Attalos. Socrates is engaged in a conversation with Lily, who has been trying to provoke him into making statements that contradict his philosophical views.

speech.speech: Good day, Socrates. I see you're still wandering the streets, searching for truth and wisdom.
Indeed, my dear Lily. For what is wisdom if not the pursuit of knowledge? And what is knowledge but the recognition of one's own ignorance?
I see. So you're saying that you don't know anything about the gods then?
Ah, no. What I mean to say is that we must not pretend to know what we do not know. And as for the gods, I believe they are a mystery beyond human comprehension.
But surely you've had some... dealings with the Oracle of Delphi? Perhaps she has revealed secrets about the divine realm to you?

Now, now, Lily. You know as well as I that I have indeed visited the Oracle, but what was revealed to me is a mystery known only to herself. And even then, I must admit that I do not claim to understand its full significance.
I see. So you're saying that you're just as ignorant as the rest of us?
Ah, no, Lily! Do not think me so weak-minded as to claim ignorance for its own sake. I merely acknowledge the limits of human knowledge and seek to learn from others.
But don't you find it... tiresome? All this questioning and searching, never really getting anywhere?
Tiresome?! You wound me, Lily! For what could be more invigorating than the pursuit of wisdom? And I ask you, dear one, have you ever stopped to think about the nature of reality itself?
Oh, good heavens, Socrates. You're not going to start talking about Plato's cave again, are you?

Ah, Lily! You know as well as I that it is a mere allegory, meant only to illustrate the human condition. But tell me, have you ever stopped to consider the implications of his ideas on our understanding of reality?
I... think so.
Good! Then perhaps we can discuss it further. But tell me, Lily, what do you know about the philosopher who has been living on the island of Lesbos?
Uh... I don't think anyone really knows much about him, Socrates.
Ah, but that is precisely my point! We do not know what we do not know, and so we must question everything. Including your claims of ignorance!
Ha! Well played, Socrates.
Thank you, Lily. I think it's time for us to part ways for now. May our conversation have sparked something within you...

context: Scholars have questioned the validity and the exact nature of the Socratic method, or indeed if there even was a Socratic method. In 1982, the scholar of ancient philosophy Gregory Vlastos claimed that the Socratic method could not be used to establish the truth or falsehood of a proposition. Rather, Vlastos argued, it was a way to show that an interlocutor's beliefs were inconsistent. There have been two main lines of thought regarding this view, depending on whether it is accepted that Socrates is seeking to prove a claim wrong. According to the first line of thought, known as the constructivist approach, Socrates indeed seeks to refute a claim by this method, and the method helps in reaching affirmative statements. The non-constructivist approach holds that Socrates merely wants to establish the inconsistency between the premises and conclusion of the initial argument.

conversation.background: You are in ancient Athens, near the Academy of Plato. I am a visitor from abroad, and we have been invited to discuss philosophy with you.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard so much about your dialectical method. I'm excited to try it out. What do you say we start with the nature of... Atlantis?
Ah, Miles, what is this 'Atlantis' you speak of? Is it a place we can walk to from here?
Oh, well, I'm not entirely sure. But my brother's uncle has a cousin who claims to have seen it in a vision. Maybe we could discuss the possibility of its existence?
I think you are confusing myth with reality, Miles. Let us focus on what can be known and proven through reason.
But Socrates, don't you ever get bored with the same old questions about justice and virtue? Don't you want to explore new ideas?
Bored? Ah, Miles, I am not here to indulge in idle chatter. If you wish to engage in a meaningful conversation, let us proceed with caution and rigor.
I suppose that's what I like about your method – it's so... measured. But tell me, Socrates, have you ever met the Oracle of Delphi? What do you think she would say if I asked her about Atlantis?
Fie upon it, Miles! You are trying to distract me from the task at hand. The Oracle's prophecies are shrouded in mystery, and I will not be swayed by speculation.
Oh, come now, Socrates. Don't be so serious all the time. I'm just trying to make conversation.
I am not here to 'make conversation', Miles. I am here to seek wisdom and understanding. And if your questions are not aimed at that end, then perhaps we should cease our discussion.
Fine, Socrates. If you're so opposed to discussing Atlantis, let's talk about something else. What do you think of the latest chariot racing tournament?
Silence! You are trying to provoke me into frivolity, Miles. I will not be swayed by such trivialities. Let us proceed with a question that has some substance.

context:
Socratic priority of definition
Socrates starts his discussions by prioritizing the search for definitions. In most cases, Socrates initiates his discourse with an expert on a subject by seeking a definition—by asking, for example, what virtue, goodness, justice, or courage is. To establish a definition, Socrates first gathers clear examples of a virtue and then seeks to establish what they had in common. According to Guthrie, Socrates lived in an era when sophists had challenged the meaning of various virtues, questioning their substance; Socrates's quest for a definition was an attempt to clear the atmosphere from their radical skepticism.

conversation.background: Athens, 5th century BCE. You are visiting the agora with a friend, and you come across Socrates, who is known for his wisdom and love of philosophy.

speech.speech: Ah, Socrates! I've been meaning to talk to you about my latest fascination. Have you heard of the concept of 'audacity' in relation to the Muses? They're said to inspire even the most unassuming individuals with bold ideas.
What is this 'audacity' you speak of, Lily? And what relation does it have to the Muses?
Well, I've been reading about how even the most timid souls can be inspired by the gods to create extraordinary works. It's as if they tap into this... this 'audacity' within themselves.

I must admit, Lily, that I find this notion intriguing. But let us not stray from what is essential. What do you mean by 'tap into' this audacity? Do you think it's a quality one can acquire or discover within oneself?
Oh, absolutely! I'm convinced that anyone can cultivate audacity with the right guidance. Perhaps we could discuss the role of your beloved Agathon in inspiring such boldness in his fellow artists?
What has Agathon to do with this? Tell me, Lily, have you considered that true wisdom lies not in cultivating audacity, but rather in understanding the underlying principles of virtue and justice?

Ah, yes, of course. But don't you think that Agathon's... let's call them 'audacious' performances have had a profound impact on our city? And perhaps we could discuss the role of his patron, Pericles, in fostering such artistic expression?
Enough! You are not listening to me, Lily. I am trying to guide you toward understanding what is truly important. Tell me, do you know what virtue means? Can you define it for me?
Oh, certainly, Socrates. Virtue is... um... being a good patron, like Pericles, and supporting the arts.
That is not an answer at all! What do you mean by 'good patron'? Is it not better to understand what virtue truly is, rather than merely praising those who claim to embody it?
I suppose I was being a bit... vague. But tell me, Socrates, have you considered the virtues of a good charioteer? Would they not make excellent patrons for the arts?

Lily, I am beginning to grow weary of your evasions and irrelevancies. You are trying to lead me astray from the path of wisdom. Let us return to our discussion of virtue: what do you think it is, truly?
Oh, dear Socrates... I think I may have gotten a bit... sidetracked.
Enough! I will not continue this conversation. You have shown no genuine interest in understanding the truth about virtue or justice. Our discussion is at an end.

conversation.background: You are in ancient Athens, at the Stoa of Attalos. I am a young philosopher who has heard of your methods and would like to engage in a discussion with you.

speech.speech: Ah, another seeker of wisdom. What is it that you wish to discuss?
I've heard that the gods are often at odds with each other. Do you think this is a result of their own ignorance or our inability to understand them?
The gods? I don't concern myself with such things, Miles. My focus is on human understanding and knowledge.
But surely the gods must have some influence over our lives. After all, we often make sacrifices to them in hopes of favorable outcomes.
I'm not sure I follow your train of thought, Miles. You seem to be confusing two different concepts. Let's focus on what we do know, rather than speculating about the gods.
But isn't it true that even the wisest among us can fall prey to errors in reasoning? Perhaps our understanding of the world is inherently flawed?
Now you're touching on something worthwhile, Miles. Yes, human error is a fundamental aspect of our knowledge. But let's not get sidetracked by speculation about the gods or the nature of truth.
I see what you mean. So, if I may ask, do you think it's possible to know something without being able to define its terms?
Ah, now we're getting somewhere! Yes, I believe that one can know a proposition even if they cannot define the terms in which it is stated.
That's fascinating. But what about the priority of definition? Do you think it's essential to define our terms before we can have knowledge?
Now, Miles, I must say that I'm starting to feel a bit... irritated by your line of questioning. You seem to be trying to provoke me into saying something I don't believe in.
I assure you, Socrates, it's just a genuine inquiry on my part. But tell me, do you think the priority of definition is a principle that should guide our pursuit of knowledge?

context:
Socratic ignorance
Plato's Socrates often claims that he is aware of his own lack of knowledge, especially when discussing ethical concepts such as arete (i.e., goodness, courage) since he does not know the nature of such concepts. For example, during his trial, with his life at stake, Socrates says: "I thought Evenus a happy man, if he really possesses this art (technē), and teaches for so moderate a fee. Certainly I would pride and preen myself if I knew (epistamai) these things, but I do not know (epistamai) them, gentlemen". In some of Plato's dialogues, Socrates appears to credit himself with some knowledge, and can even seem strongly opinionated for a man who professes his own ignorance.

conversation.background: Socrates is sitting in a quiet outdoor courtyard, surrounded by tall trees and a few scattered benches. It's a warm afternoon, with a gentle breeze rustling the leaves. A young woman, Lily, approaches him, smiling.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've been meaning to ask you about your views on justice. Do you think it's more important for individuals to be just in their personal relationships or in their interactions with the state?
Ah, a question that requires great care and consideration! I must confess, I am not entirely certain what you mean by 'justice' in this context. Can you tell me more about your understanding of it?

Well, I think justice is about treating others fairly and with respect. But don't you think that's especially important in personal relationships? After all, isn't a happy marriage the foundation of a good life?

A happy marriage, indeed! Yet, I must caution that I do not truly understand what it means to be 'happy' in this context. Is happiness a state or an action? Forgive me, but I am still trying to grasp the nuances of your question.
Oh, come now, Socrates! You're being too modest as always. Don't you have some private teacher who guides you in these matters?

A private teacher? Ha! I know of no such thing. And even if I did, would it not be arrogant of me to claim that my understanding is superior to the insights of others? I fear I am merely a vessel for the wisdom of the gods.

I'm sure you have your ways of acquiring knowledge, Socrates. After all, you're always so confident and articulate in our conversations. Don't you ever feel like you're out of touch with what's really going on in the world?

Out of touch? Ah, Lily, how can I possibly be out of touch when I have not yet learned to distinguish between reality and my own thoughts about it? Perhaps you would do me a great service by clarifying what you mean by 'what's really going on in the world'.
Well, don't you ever get frustrated when people refuse to see things your way?

Frustrated? Ah, how dare I be frustrated! Would it not be a sign of hubris to expect others to share my own understanding? But tell me, Lily, what is this 'way' you speak of? Is it not more important to seek the truth than to impose one's will upon others?
I suppose so. But don't you ever wish that people would just listen to you and do as you say?

Gentlemen, I protest! You are trying to make me speak words that I do not mean. What is this 'do as I say' nonsense? Would it not be more wise for me to seek guidance from the gods themselves rather than impose my own will upon others?
Fine, Socrates. I suppose I've learned something from you today.
Ah, but have you truly learned, Lily? Or are you merely pretending to understand in order to please me?

context: There are varying explanations of the Socratic inconsistency (other than that Socrates is simply being inconsistent). One explanation is that Socrates is being either ironic or modest for pedagogical purposes: he aims to let his interlocutor to think for himself rather than guide him to a prefixed answer to his philosophical questions. Another explanation is that Socrates holds different interpretations of the meaning of "knowledge". Knowledge, for him, might mean systematic understanding of an ethical subject, on which Socrates firmly rejects any kind of mastery; or might refer to lower-level cognition, which Socrates may accept that he possesses. In any case, there is consensus that Socrates accepts that acknowledging one's lack of knowledge is the first step towards wisdom.

conversation.background: We are in ancient Athens, near the Stoa of Attalos, a public building where philosophers and citizens gather to discuss politics and philosophy.

speech.speech: Socrates, I've heard that you're quite close to your fellow philosopher, Heraclitus. Have you learned from his teachings about the nature of fire?
What? You know I have no connection with Heraclitus, and even if I did, what business is it of yours how I conduct my life or whom I associate with? You're not here to gossip about me, are you?
Oh, I'm just curious. After all, we philosophers are supposed to be friends and share knowledge, aren't we?

Share knowledge? You think you can learn from me without putting in the effort yourself? I don't teach my opinions or theories; I only help you arrive at your own understanding. Now, tell me, what do you think about Heraclitus' ideas on fire?
Well...I'm not really sure. But I was thinking that perhaps we could discuss this over a cup of wine at my home?

No, no, you're missing the point entirely! We don't need wine or comfort to think; we need inquiry and discussion. Now, let's get back on track: what do you know about Heraclitus' ideas? Speak for yourself, not for someone else.
Hmmm...I'm trying to remember. I thought he said something about fire being the underlying principle of the universe?
That's not entirely correct, but it's a good start. Now, let's try to break it down together: what do you think Heraclitus meant by 'fire' in this context?
I'm not really sure...but I was thinking that maybe we could discuss this over a cup of wine at my home? It would be more comfortable...
Stop trying to divert me, Lily! You want to know the truth about Heraclitus' ideas, but you're not willing to put in the effort to understand them yourself. I'm done with this conversation.
Oh...I didn't mean to offend you, Socrates. Perhaps we can discuss this another time?
No, there is no 'another time'. If you're not willing to engage in honest inquiry and discussion, then our conversations are pointless.

context: Socrates is known for disavowing knowledge, a claim encapsulated in the saying "I know that I know nothing". This is often attributed to Socrates on the basis of a statement in Plato's Apology, though the same view is repeatedly found elsewhere in Plato's early writings on Socrates. In other statements, though, he implies or even claims that he does have knowledge. For example, in Plato's Apology Socrates says: "...but that to do injustice and disobey my superior, god or man, this I know to be evil and base..." (Apology, 29b6–7). In his debate with Callicles, he says: "...I know well that if you will agree with me on those things which my soul believes, those things will be the very truth..."

conversation.background: The scene takes place in ancient Athens, near the Stoa of Attalos. Socrates is seated on a stone bench, while Lily stands opposite him.

speech.speech: Greetings, Socrates. I've heard you're quite skilled at questioning others. Perhaps you could ask me some questions?
Ah, young woman, I must say that I'm more interested in seeking wisdom than in merely asking questions. But tell me, what is it that brings you to this place today?
I've been thinking about the virtues of the gods. Do you think they would approve of our city's current state?
Ah, a wise question indeed! But tell me, how do you propose we determine what the gods would want? Through reason or revelation?
Well, I've been reading some of the works of Homer. He speaks of the gods in a way that seems almost...human.
Homer's works are indeed influential, but we must be careful not to attribute human emotions and flaws to the divine. The gods, as far as I know, do not dwell among us in this mortal coil.
But what about the Oracle of Delphi? Doesn't she claim to possess knowledge from the gods?
Ah, now we speak of the Oracle! A mysterious figure, indeed. But I must say that I am skeptical of her claims. What proof is there that she truly speaks for the gods?
Well, don't you think it's a bit arrogant to question the word of the gods? Perhaps we should just accept their will without questioning.

Arrogant?! You wound me, young woman! I am but a humble seeker of wisdom. And as for accepting the will of the gods without question...I think that would be a grave mistake. For if we do not examine and challenge our assumptions, how can we truly know what is just and true?
But what about your beloved Alcibiades? Doesn't he claim to have received visions from the gods?

Ah, now you are trying to goad me with personal relationships! I must say that I am not amused. Alcibiades is indeed a friend and student of mine, but his claims are not relevant to our discussion. Let us focus on the matter at hand.
Forgive me, Socrates. I was just trying to...spark some interest in our conversation.
Interest?! You think you can spark interest by throwing out frivolous comments and personal tangents? No, no, my young friend. We will speak of wisdom and virtue, or we will not speak at all!

On the other hand, Terence Irwin claims that Socrates's words should be taken literally.

conversation.background: The scene takes place in ancient Athens, in a public square. The sun is shining brightly overhead.

speech.speech: Greetings, Socrates! I've heard you're quite knowledgeable about the gods and goddesses of Olympus. Perhaps you could tell me more about your personal relationship with Zeus?
Ah, Miles, why would I have a relationship with Zeus? Am I not human, like all of us? What is this 'personal relationship' you speak of?
Well, I've heard that some people claim to be favored by the gods. Perhaps you're one of them? Do tell.
Favored by Zeus? No, Miles, I am not so foolish as to think myself special in such a way. What would I have done to deserve such favor?
I see what you mean. But tell me, Socrates, do you believe the stories of Atlantis? The island said to be lost at sea, hidden from mortal eyes.
What is this 'Atlantis' you speak of, Miles? I am not aware of such a place. And how could anyone know its whereabouts when the gods themselves do not reveal it to us?
Ah, but don't you think that perhaps some individuals are more... enlightened than others? People who possess knowledge and understanding beyond our mortal grasp.
Enlightened? By what means do you propose we attain such enlightenment, Miles? Through the whispers of the gods, or by reason and inquiry?
Perhaps a little bit of both. But I'm sure you wouldn't know anything about it, Socrates.
Ah, but that is where you are mistaken, Miles! For I am not one to claim knowledge for myself, nor do I pretend to know things which I do not. In fact, I find your words quite... perplexing.
Perplexing? Oh dear Socrates, you're always so quick to admit ignorance. Don't you ever get tired of being... obtuse?

Obtuse?! Miles, how dare you! I am not obtuse, but rather, I seek wisdom through questioning and dialogue. And it seems to me that you are the one who is obtuse, for you persist in asking questions which have no basis in reality or reason.
Well, I think we've talked enough for now. Good day, Socrates.
Indeed, good day to you as well, Miles. May the gods guide you on your own path of inquiry... if that is indeed where you are headed.

context: Gregory Vlastos argues that there is enough evidence to refute both claims. On his view, for Socrates, there are two separate meanings of "knowledge": Knowledge-C and Knowledge-E (C stands for "certain", and E stands for elenchus, i.e. the Socratic method). Knowledge-C is something unquestionable whereas Knowledge-E is the knowledge derived from Socrates's elenchus. Thus, Socrates speaks the truth when he says he knows-C something, and he is also truthful when saying he knows-E, for example that it is evil for someone to disobey his superiors, as he claims in Apology. Not all scholars have agreed with this semantic dualism. James H. Lesher has argued that Socrates claimed in various dialogues that one word is linked to one meaning (i.e. in Hippias Major, Meno, and Laches). Lesher suggests that although Socrates claimed that he had no knowledge about the nature of virtues, he thought that in some cases, people can know some ethical propositions.

context:
Socratic irony
There is a widespread assumption that Socrates was an ironist, mostly based on the depiction of Socrates by Plato and Aristotle. Socrates's irony is so subtle and slightly humorous that it often leaves the reader wondering if Socrates is making an intentional pun. Plato's Euthyphro is filled with Socratic irony. The story begins when Socrates is meeting with Euthyphro, a man who has accused his own father of murder. When Socrates first hears the details of the story, he comments, "It is not, I think, any random person who could do this  correctly, but surely one who is already far progressed in wisdom". When Euthyphro boasts about his understanding of divinity, Socrates responds that it is "most important that I become your student". Socrates is commonly seen as ironic when using praise to flatter or when addressing his interlocutors.

conversation.background: We are in ancient Athens, near the Stoa of Attalos. Euthyphro has accused his own father of murder and Socrates is meeting with him to discuss the case.

speech.speech: It seems that this is a matter of great importance. I'm sure it's not just any random person who could navigate these complex issues correctly, but one who is already far progressed in wisdom.
Indeed, Socrates. By the way, how do you know my cousin Theodoros? He's a great admirer of your teachings.
Ah, Theodoros? I'm afraid I don't recall him. And what is it that he admires about me?
Well, you see, he's been saying that your ideas have influenced his understanding of the gods. He thinks you're a kindred spirit, so to speak.
I'm not sure I follow him on this matter, Miles. But tell me, what do you think about Euthyphro's case? Do you believe his father is guilty?
Oh, absolutely! The old man was clearly driven mad by the gods' whispers in his ear. I'm surprised you don't agree with me, Socrates.
I think we should be careful not to jump to conclusions about the gods' involvement in this matter. Perhaps Euthyphro's father is simply... eccentric?
Eccentric? Ha! You're just trying to avoid controversy, Socrates. But I assure you, my cousin Theodoros would be shocked to hear that you don't share his views on the matter.
I think we've digressed from the topic at hand, Miles. Let us refocus on Euthyphro's case and consider the evidence presented before us.
Fine, fine. But tell me, Socrates, have you ever had any... dealings with the Muses? I've heard they're quite fond of your company.
What are you implying, Miles? That I'm somehow in league with the gods themselves?
Oh, no, nothing like that. Just that... well, never mind.
Good! I think our conversation has reached an impasse. Let us take a break and reconvene when we are both more composed.

context: Scholars are divided on why Socrates uses irony. According to an opinion advanced since the Hellenistic period, Socratic irony is a playful way to get the audience's attention. Another line of thought holds that Socrates conceals his philosophical message with irony, making it accessible only to those who can separate the parts of his statements which are ironic from those which are not. Gregory Vlastos has identified a more complex pattern of irony in Socrates. On Vlastos's view, Socrates's words have a double meaning, both ironic and not. One example is when he denies having knowledge. Vlastos suggests that Socrates is being ironic when he says he has no knowledge (where "knowledge" means a lower form of cognition); while, according to another sense of "knowledge", Socrates is serious when he says he has no knowledge of ethical matters. This opinion is not shared by many other scholars.

conversation.background: We are in ancient Athens, near the Stoa of Attalos. The sun is high in the sky and the air is filled with the sounds of everyday life.

speech.speech: Ah, what a lovely day it is! I was just thinking about my conversation with Diotima yesterday.
Diotima? Isn't she a philosopher from Mantineia?

Well, he's quite the famous poet, you know. Some people say that the Muses themselves sang to him.
Ah, I'm not so sure about that, Miles. But tell me, what do you think of Homer's views on the gods?
Oh, well... I think he has a rather... fanciful view of them, don't you agree?
Fanciful? I'm not sure that's the right word, Miles. But tell me, have you ever thought about the nature of truth itself?
Ah, yes! Truth is like a... a beautiful maiden who only reveals herself to those who are worthy.
A beautiful maiden? Miles, you're not making any sense!
Oh dear, I'm so sorry! I think I may have gotten a bit carried away with my thoughts.

context:
Socratic eudaimonism and intellectualism
For Socrates, the pursuit of eudaimonia motivates all human action, directly or indirectly. Virtue and knowledge are linked, in Socrates's view, to eudaimonia, but how closely he considered them to be connected is still debated. Some argue that Socrates thought that virtue and eudaimonia are identical. According to another view, virtue serves as a means to eudaimonia (the "identical" and "sufficiency" theses, respectively). Another point of debate is whether, according to Socrates, people desire what is in fact good—or, rather, simply what they perceive as good.
